[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Supermarket System (SMS) defines authentication, connectivity, transaction security, and availability requirements.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: SMS supports network efficiency, access control, uptime monitoring, and IT compliance.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: SMS integrates with authentication, network monitoring, and transaction processing databases.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: SMS provides a web-based UI for staff and administrators.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: SMS runs on supermarket networks and cloud servers.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: SMS uses a React.js frontend, Node.js backend, and PostgreSQL for secure data storage.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: SMS ensures encrypted data transmission via TLS 1.3.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: SMS manages user authentication, real-time transaction processing, and system uptime monitoring.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: SMS ensures stable connectivity, platform independence, and real-time system monitoring.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: SMS connects to authentication, security monitoring, and transaction APIs.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: SMS ensures authentication, speed, system availability, and IT compliance.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: SMS is designed for staff, admins, and IT managers handling security and operations.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.6 Limitations: SMS requires stable connectivity for transactions and monitoring.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: SMS relies on encryption, stable internet, and uptime monitoring.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Secure Authentication: Encrypted access and roles.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall integrate with authentication and network monitoring services.
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall enforce role-based authentication for employees, managers, and administrators.

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall restrict access based on operational hours (REQ-INTF-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide an intuitive UI with optimized transaction flow for supermarket staff (REQ-INTF-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall ensure real-time transaction processing with minimal latency (REQ-INTF-001).
[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-002: The system shall maintain 99.5% uptime with continuous server monitoring (REQ-INTF-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall securely store credentials, transaction logs, and performance records (REQ-INTF-002).

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall enforce SHA-2 encryption for password storage.
[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-002: The system shall restrict back-end access to authenticated administrators.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with encryption, authentication, and security best practices (REQ-DSGN-001).

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall ensure high availability, security, and real-time monitoring for network threats (REQ-DSGN-002, REQ-COMP-001).

[SEC] 3. Verification: Network speed, authentication security, uptime, and transaction performance validated.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, API documentation, system performance guidelines, and security policies.
[SEC] 5. References: Network protocols, authentication best practices, uptime guidelines, and database security standards.
